meanings.definition: A thing tacitly assumed beforehand at the beginning of a line of argument or course of action.
meanings.sent1: Her presupposition that everyone would agree with her plan led to disappointment when they didn't.
meanings.sent2: The success of the project was based on the presupposition that all team members would fulfill their roles.
meanings.sent3: His presupposition that the cat could understand his complex instructions made for a humorous situation.
meanings.sent4: The presupposition that the sun would rise every morning was shattered during the eclipse.
meanings.sent5: The presupposition that hard work always leads to success is not always true in every situation.

meanings.definition: A condition taken for granted or accepted as true without proof.
meanings.sent1: The presupposition that honesty is always the best policy is a common belief.
meanings.sent2: In science, researchers often work based on the presupposition that their experiments will yield accurate results.
meanings.sent3: The presupposition that eating cake for breakfast is healthy is a funny notion.
meanings.sent4: The presupposition that money can buy happiness is a flawed concept.
meanings.sent5: The presupposition that all politicians are corrupt is a stereotype that is not always accurate.
